0.text: Hello everyone, welcome to another episode of the Daily Gwei Refuel, where we recap the latest news in the ETHereum ecosystem.

1.text: I'm your host, Anthony Sassano and this is the 26th of April 2023.

2.text: Alright everyone, let's get into it.

3.text: So I spoke yesterday about Coinbase's suit against the SEC and gave some details about that.

4.text: Well, I just wanted to highlight this thread today from a Meta Lawman who explained in a bit more detail about what this is actually going to entail.

5.text: So he says here, this case begins in the appellate court, not the trial court.

6.text: There will be no discovery, depositions and document exchanges, just briefing and a hearing.

7.text: Coinbase has an all-star legal team led by Eugene Scalia, former Secretary of Labor and son of deceased Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia.

8.text: Scalia has experience defeating government agencies, including the SEC in court.

9.text: The petition filed yesterday is quite persuasive.

10.text: Then he continues by saying Coinbase is seeking a writ of mandamus, which is a court order complying the SEC to do its job and announce a decision on Coinbase's request for rulemaking.

11.text: This action does not necessarily affect the SEC's timing for suing Coinbase as it is threatened to do so.

12.text: And then he continues and says he expects major industry players to pile in with amicus briefs supporting Coinbase's position.

13.text: We might also see the House Financial Services Committee or individual members come in with briefs in support of Coinbase.

14.text: And this is where it gets really juicy.

15.text: The SEC commissioners will have to approve any response to Coinbase's action.

16.text: There's a tiny chance that the SEC will blink and agree to engage in rulemaking.

17.text: And if just one commissioner withdraws their support for Gary Gensler's regulation by enforcement strategy, he's done.

18.text: Now, I don't know what he's done means here.

19.text: I don't know if that means like he's fired or if he'll be removed or something like that.

20.text: I'm not across it as much as I would like to be.

21.text: But when I read he's done, I'm like, OK, well, maybe he actually does get removed.

23.text: Maybe there isn't just those two kind of options that I talked about yesterday and a couple of weeks ago.

24.text: And I'm just going to quickly look in here and see if there's any replies here.

25.text: OK, yeah. So he's replied here.

26.text: To be clear, I mean, one of the Democratic appointed commissioners who have been supporting the regulation by enforcement strategy to date.

27.text: OK, so he didn't mean Gary Gensler would be done.

28.text: It meant that the commissioner would be done.

29.text: OK, so that that makes a bit more sense, I guess.

31.text: This is a great little breakdown here.

32.text: And I'll link in the Youtube description below.

33.text: But I think that's it on that one, because I spoke about this a lot yesterday.

34.text: So if you missed me speaking about it yesterday, go check out yesterday's episode there.

35.text: And I'll keep you guys updated on how Coinbase's suit goes here.

36.text: All right. So that DevNet 5 for EIP 4844 that I've been talking about has an update today.

37.text: So FLCL here on Twitter, who is a dev at Nethermind, put out a tweet saying

38.text: Nethermind has the fifth iteration of EIP4844 implemented, now syncs with Loadstar.

39.text: Waiting for the DevNet V5 full start.

40.text: By the way, what's new in V5?

41.text: So V5 changes make 4844 simpler and cleaner.

43.text: Shard blob transactions now must have at least one blob and no aggregated proof.

44.text: A commitment and a proof for every blob, which allows to verify faster.

45.text: And then a few other things here, which you can read in the YouTube description below.

46.text: And Terrence from the Prylabs team also put out a tweet saying two weeks ago shipped

47.text: Capella or I guess like Shapella.

48.text: Capella is the consensus layer side of things, which is what Terrence works on.

49.text: And this week, Prism syncing multi-client Deneb DevNet 5.

50.text: Deneb is part of the Cancun upgrade that is happening at the end of the year

52.text: Yeah, so there is a lot of progress being made very quickly on 4844

53.text: now that Shapella is behind us.

54.text: And I remember I've said this over the last few months, that as soon as Shapella was done,

55.text: I mean, even leading up to it being done on mainnet,

56.text: sorry, being deployed on mainnet, 4844 was making very good progress.

57.text: Now, I am growing more and more confident by the day that we're going to be able

58.text: to see 4844 go live on mainnet by end of this year.

60.text: of them, as we've seen with some of the applications

61.text: or some of the services built on top of ETHereum, such as Lido.

63.text: until at least a month after Shapella went live

219.text: And then I've also seen the amount of ETH at stake number be

220.text: be inaccurately shown on certain websites.

221.text: And that's because they are just looking at the ETH2 deposit contract.

222.text: So I have to explain this because I don't think many people are aware of this.

223.text: The ETH2 deposit contract is a one way burn,

224.text: which means you send ETH in there to enter into ETH staking.

225.text: And it burns that ETH technically on the execution layer side

226.text: and issues it on the consensus layer side, which allows you to continue staking.

227.text: And then when you go to withdraw it,

228.text: it does not reduce the balance of the ETH2 deposit contract,

230.text: May in the future, but it doesn't right now.

231.text: Now, this is not an accounting error.

232.text: This is not a bug. This is working as intended.

233.text: So as you can see, the ETH2 deposit contract has 19.4 million ETH in it.

234.text: Now, this is ETH that has been effectively burned.

235.text: It is not ETH that can be withdrawn from this contract.

236.text: It is, as I said, is a one way bridge into the consensus layer into staking.

237.text: Now you can see here on the BeaconChain website,

238.text: it says that the staked ETH is at 18 million.

239.text: So that is a pretty large discrepancy there.

240.text: Well, that's because any ETH that is withdrawn from the BeaconChain

241.text: as a full exit, right, as a full exit of the validator

242.text: does not come from this contract.

243.text: It comes from the consensus layer itself, which is where the ETH is actually stored.

244.text: And as I said, that means that this contract is going to be up only

246.text: There may be a reconciliation of balances one day where the contract is,

247.text: where there is a kind of a hard fork to do this.

248.text: But it may not be something that gets done because it may not be.

249.text: There may not be any point to it.

252.text: or it has always been up only.

253.text: But when the validators withdraw, it's not going to show here.
